definitions: eat or drink something especially in a formal or ceremonial context
take part in or become involved in an activity or event
examples: The guests will partake of the wedding feast tonight
Would you like to partake in some refreshments before leaving
All employees are encouraged to partake in the team building exercises
The children eagerly partake in the holiday celebrations each year

definitions: divide something into parts or sections especially by putting up a wall or barrier
examples: The company decided to partition the large office into smaller cubicles
They will partition the room with a movable screen for privacy

definitions: stick something to a surface using a thick sticky substance or glue
insert text or data that has been copied from one place into another location
examples: The children paste colorful pictures onto their art project books
She will paste the wallpaper carefully to avoid any air bubbles
You can copy this text and paste it into your document
Just paste the link into the browser's address bar to visit

definitions: put farm animals in a field to feed on grass and plants
examples: The farmer will pasture his cattle in the meadow during summer
They pasture their sheep on the hillside where grass grows abundantly

definitions: touch someone or something gently and repeatedly with the flat of your hand
examples: She likes to pat her dog's head when he behaves well
The mother will pat the baby's back to help him sleep

definitions: give financial support or regular custom to a business, organization, or person
examples: Many locals patronage the family-owned restaurant that opened last year
The wealthy couple will patronage several artists in the community gallery

definitions: make a series of light tapping sounds like rain or small feet
speak rapidly and continuously in a practiced or meaningless way
examples: Rain began to patter softly against the bedroom window panes
We could hear mice patter across the attic floor at night
The salesman will patter on about the product's amazing features endlessly
The auctioneer can patter faster than anyone else I've ever heard

definitions: cover a road or path with stones, bricks, concrete, or similar hard material
examples: The city plans to pave all the dirt roads by next summer
Workers will pave the parking lot with fresh asphalt this weekend

definitions: touch or scrape with a paw or hoof like an animal does
touch or handle someone or something roughly, clumsily, or in an unwanted way
examples: The horse will paw at the ground when it feels impatient
My cat likes to paw at the door when she wants inside
Please don't paw through my personal belongings without asking first
The children paw at the toys until their parents buy them

definitions: leave an item with a pawnbroker as security for money borrowed
use a person or thing for one's own advantage or purpose
examples: He had to pawn his watch to pay for the car repairs
Many people pawn their jewelry when they need quick cash
The company will pawn its junior employees to do all the tedious work
Politicians often pawn voters' trust for their own personal gain

definitions: inform on someone or reveal their wrongdoing to an authority figure
examples: The gang member threatened to peach on his accomplices for a lighter sentence
She would never peach on her friends no matter what happened

definitions: ring out loudly and clearly especially referring to bells or similar sounds
examples: The church bells peal every Sunday morning to call people to service
Thunder began to peal across the dark sky during the storm

definitions: form drops or beads that look like pearls especially on a surface
dive underwater to search for and collect pearls from oysters
examples: Morning dew will pearl on the spider's web creating a beautiful sight
Sweat began to pearl on his forehead during the intense workout
The divers pearl in these waters during the summer months only
Local fishermen have been known to pearl here for many generations

definitions: strike or bite something with a beak or a pointed tool
give someone a quick light kiss usually on the cheek
examples: The chickens peck at the grain scattered on the ground
The woodpecker will peck holes in the tree to find insects
She will peck him on the cheek before leaving for work
The children peck their grandmother goodbye after every visit

definitions: push the pedals of a bicycle or other machine with your feet
ride a bicycle by pushing the pedals with your feet
examples: You need to pedal harder to go up this steep hill
The pianist will pedal to sustain the notes during the performance
The children pedal their bikes to school every morning together
We can pedal along the riverside path on our rented bicycles

definitions: travel around selling goods, typically in small quantities
try to sell or promote an idea or view persistently
examples: Street vendors peddle fresh fruit at the busy market square daily
He used to peddle newspapers on the corner as a young boy
Politicians peddle their promises during every election campaign season
The company will peddle its new software to potential business clients

definitions: pass urine from the body in the act of urination
examples: The toddler needs to pee before we start the long car journey
Dogs often pee on trees to mark their territory outdoors

definitions: look quickly and secretly at something especially through a small opening
examples: The children peek through the curtains to see who's at the door
Don't peek at your presents before your birthday party tomorrow

definitions: look quickly and secretly through a narrow opening or from a hidden place
make a short high-pitched sound like a young bird or mouse
examples: The curious neighbor likes to peep through her window blinds
The sun began to peep through the clouds after the storm
Baby chicks peep loudly when they're hungry for food
We heard a mouse peep from somewhere behind the kitchen cabinets

definitions: fasten or attach something with pegs, pins, or similar pointed objects
fix or set something such as prices or wages at a particular level
examples: We need to peg the tent securely to withstand strong winds
She will peg the laundry on the clothesline to dry outside
The government decided to peg fuel prices for the next six months
Many countries peg their currency to the US dollar for stability

definitions: throw things repeatedly at someone or something with force
strike heavily and repeatedly especially referring to rain or hail
examples: The angry crowd began to pelt the speaker with rotten tomatoes
Children love to pelt each other with snowballs during winter
Heavy rain will pelt against the windows throughout the night
Hailstones pelt down on the car roof during the sudden storm

definitions: punish someone for breaking a rule or law by imposing a disadvantage or penalty
examples: The referee will penalize players who commit fouls during the game
The tax office can penalize late filers with substantial monetary fees

definitions: write, draw, or mark something using a pencil
arrange or schedule something provisionally that may be changed later
examples: Students should pencil their names at the top of the test paper
The artist will pencil the initial sketch before adding paint
Let's pencil in a meeting for next Tuesday afternoon
I'll pencil you down for the 3 o'clock appointment slot

definitions: go into or through something especially when this is difficult
understand or discover something that is difficult to understand or hidden
examples: The nail can easily penetrate through the thin wooden board
Sunlight struggles to penetrate the dense forest canopy overhead
It took years to penetrate the mystery of the ancient symbols
Few people can penetrate his reserved and quiet personality

definitions: sit or rest on something high or narrow like a bird
place something on a high or precarious position
examples: Birds perch on the telephone wires outside my bedroom window
The cat likes to perch on top of the bookshelf
She will perch her reading glasses on top of her head
The village perch precariously on the steep mountain slope

definitions: give a pleasant smell to something by adding perfume or aromatic substances
examples: The roses perfume the entire garden with their sweet fragrance
She likes to perfume her letters with a drop of lavender oil

definitions: put someone or something at risk or in danger of harm or loss
examples: Reckless driving will peril the lives of innocent pedestrians on the road
Don't peril your health by ignoring the doctor's important advice

definitions: die or be destroyed especially in a sudden or violent way
decay or rot over time until no longer existing or usable
examples: Many soldiers perish in battle defending their homeland from invaders
The flowers will perish without water during the hot summer days
Food will perish quickly if not stored in the refrigerator properly
The rubber seals perish over time and need regular replacement

definitions: become more cheerful, lively, or energetic often suddenly
make coffee in a percolator by forcing hot water through grounds
examples: The students perk up when the teacher announces an early dismissal
The dog's ears perk when he hears his owner's car approaching
I'll perk some fresh coffee for our morning meeting
The coffee should perk for about ten minutes before serving

definitions: give hair a permanent wave or curl using chemicals and heat
examples: She decided to perm her straight hair for a new curly look
The hairstylist will perm your hair to last several months

definitions: spread throughout something and be present in every part of it
examples: The smell of fresh bread permeate through the entire bakery
His influence permeate every aspect of the company's corporate culture

definitions: bleach something, especially hair, using hydrogen peroxide or similar chemical
examples: She wants to peroxide her dark hair to achieve a platinum blonde color
The dentist may peroxide your teeth to make them appear whiter

definitions: make something continue indefinitely or for a very long time
examples: These outdated policies perpetuate inequality in our education system
We must not perpetuate harmful stereotypes through our media content

definitions: treat someone cruelly or unfairly especially because of their race, religion, or political beliefs
examples: The regime continues to persecute journalists who criticize the government
Throughout history, many groups have been persecute for their religious beliefs

definitions: continue trying to do something despite difficulties, obstacles, or discouragement
examples: Students must persevere through challenging coursework to earn their degrees
She will persevere with her training despite the painful injury

definitions: relate to or be connected with a particular subject, person, or situation
examples: These rules pertain only to full-time employees of the company
The new regulations pertain to all vehicles manufactured after this year

definitions: change something from its correct use or original purpose in a harmful way
examples: Some people pervert religious teachings to justify their violent actions
Don't pervert the truth to make yourself look better than others

definitions: grind or crush substances using a pestle tool in a mortar bowl
examples: The chef will pestle fresh herbs to release their aromatic oils
You need to pestle the spices thoroughly for the curry paste

definitions: have casual sexual relationships with multiple people, especially when married or committed
examples: He would philander with other women despite being happily married
The novel's protagonist philander throughout the story without any remorse

definitions: make a paper copy of a document or image using a photocopying machine
examples: Please photocopy these important documents for our office records
Students can photocopy relevant pages from library books for studying

definitions: alter or enhance a digital image using photo editing software
examples: The magazine will photoshop models to remove any perceived flaws
He can photoshop old family photos to restore their original quality

definitions: stand outside a workplace or venue to protest and discourage others from entering
examples: Workers plan to picket the factory until their demands are met
Union members will picket peacefully outside the company headquarters tomorrow

definitions: preserve food, especially vegetables, in vinegar or salt water
examples: My grandmother loves to pickle cucumbers from her garden every summer
You can pickle almost any vegetable using this simple recipe

definitions: have a meal outdoors, especially in a park or countryside setting
examples: The family will picnic by the lake this Sunday afternoon
Let's picnic in the botanical gardens when the weather improves

definitions: make a hole through something using a sharp pointed instrument
examples: The nurse will pierce the skin quickly with the vaccination needle
She wants to pierce her ears at the jewelry store today

definitions: color something using natural or artificial coloring substances
examples: Artists pigment their canvases with various natural and synthetic materials
The manufacturer will pigment the plastic to achieve the desired color

definitions: steal goods using violence, especially during war or civil disorder
examples: The invading army would pillage villages and take all valuable resources
Pirates used to pillage merchant ships sailing through these waters

definitions: attack or criticize someone publicly and severely
examples: The media will pillory any politician caught in a scandal
Critics pillory the director's latest film for its poor storytelling

definitions: control and profit from the activities of prostitutes
make something more showy or impressive in appearance
examples: It's illegal to pimp in most countries around the world
The criminal organization would pimp vulnerable women for profit
He wants to pimp his car with custom rims and paint
The TV show helps people pimp their boring homes into showplaces

definitions: squeeze something tightly between finger and thumb causing pain or damage
steal something, especially something of little value
examples: Don't pinch your little sister or she'll start crying again
These new shoes pinch my toes and make walking uncomfortable
Someone tried to pinch my wallet on the crowded subway train
Kids would often pinch candy from the corner store display
